Introduction

Procurement is the process of acquiring goods and services, covering both acquisitions from third parties and from in-house providers. The process spans the whole life cycle from identification of needs, management of the process and through to its expiry.

The management of Procurement is essential to the efficiency and effectiveness of both clinical and support services. Patient care depends on the guaranteed availability of quality equipment, materials and services in line with the Standing Financial Instructions and legislation around Procurement. Accountability for the expenditure of taxpayer's money requires that sound economic decisions are taken in relation to procurement.

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (the “Trust”) recognises that the provision of quality patient care is supported by using cost effective procurement process which delivers value for money. Procurement acts as a facilitator to all divisions and ensures that the Trust achieves best in care standards for its patients whilst operating within rules and regulations around the acquisition of goods and services. This can be achieved by developing supplier and customer relationships that consider whole life cost, and ensure appropriate competition.

This philosophy has been endorsed by the Lord Carter report; "NHS Procurement and Commercial Standards" which provides indicative key performance indicators and focus for Procurement Teams to achieve excellence standards in procurement (link below).
https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/nhs-procurement-standards

All procurement activity throughout the Trust will be conducted under the professional and ethical guidance provided by the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply. Public Procurement Regulations will also be adhered to, in conjunction with local Trust Standing Orders and Standing Financial Instructions

This policy sets out the principles that ensure the Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust provides an effective procurement process, good stewardship and value for money. The role of the Procurement Department can be defined as follows:
To lead and operate a comprehensive best practice supply management service, that adds value to the healthcare provision for patients by delivering value for money.
To deliver procurement services that are efficient, innovative, cost effective and continually developing for the overall benefit of the Trust and its patients.
Scope

This policy applies to all employees (permanent, seconded, contractors, management and clinical trainees, apprentices, temporary staff and volunteers) of the Trust. Third Parties with Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust
It covers all aspects of procuring goods and services for the Trust; to be read in conjunction with Corporate Governance Manual, Trusts Standing Financial Instructions and Scheme of Delegation.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust

Audit Committee – Reporting of waivers to audit to provide oversight by site and directorate as to the value and volume of waivers raised per quarter and a review of the rationales provided by directorates
Chief Finance Director – is responsible for advising the Board of Directors on thresholds above which tenders are required and for developing procedures to implement this policy.

Procurement Department – shall be responsible for monitoring compliance with this policy and ensuring all relevant legislation and government guidelines are followed. The Procurement Department is responsible for ensuring that the Procurement Strategy is implemented in accordance with this policy.

It is also the responsibility of the Procurement Department to develop procedures to cover all the Trust's non-pay expenditure that encompass the requirements of Standing Financial Instructions, Standing Orders, GPA Procurement Directives and all specific NHS/DoH Policies.
Authorised Staff – All staff authorised to purchase goods and services are required to comply with this policy and the requirements of the Corporate Governance Manual.

Staff – All staff must be aware of the controls in place for procurement and not enter into procurement agreements without appropriate authority. All staff must also remember that in line with the Trust's Scheme of Delegations, only a Responsible Executive is allowed to sign for contracts.
The Group Director of Procurement has overall responsibility for ensuring good procurement practice throughout the Trust.

The Deputy Group Director of Procurement and the Head of Operations and Logistics reports monthly on procurement performance to the Director of Procurement and the Director of Procurement reports monthly to the Finance Review Committee and Audit Committee.

Trust Managers have a key role in ensuring good procurement practice is followed when requiring to purchase goods or acquire services and therefore must be conversant with Standing Financial Instructions, Standing Orders the Procurement Policy including the Code of Practice for Company Representatives.

Staff involved in procurement must comply with Standing Financial Instructions, Standing Orders GPA Procurement Directives, Procurement Policy, Procurement Strategy and Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply code of ethics and follow procedures outlined in the Procurement Manual.
Ordering probity

There is a general duty on all public sector procurers to apply the key principles of public procurement. These require the delivery of value for money (“VFM”), appropriate quality and service to meet business needs, and appropriate governance (that is, adherence to HM Treasury rules concerning the use of public money in procurement). It is the responsibility of all managers and staff involved with procurement to understand the above and strive for best value.

The placing of a physical order with suppliers prior to receipt of goods and invoice is good business practice. Standing Financial Instructions state that an official order must be placed in advance of receipt of goods. The Trust operates a strict no order no pay policy.
An email will be sent to anyone who does not follow correct procedures advising them that this is not in accordance with Standing Financial Instructions

An order is a legally binding contract between the buyer and seller. It is important for both parties to understand which terms and conditions govern the established contract between the parties. A formal order in advance of purchase means the supplier is working from the Trust's terms and conditions. Goods purchased without a formal order from the Trust results in the Trust working to the Suppliers Terms and Conditions of Contract which could be detrimental to the Trust.

The Department of Health is responsible for drawing up standard Terms and Conditions of contract for purchase within the NHS, and these should be used for all purchases, whether one off, or period contracts. These terms and conditions are available from the Procurement Department.
Procurement currently operates the following ordering systems:
E-Financials for all other areas
SCCL electronic data capture
For all products an order must be raised in advance via E-financials & SCCL Electronic data capture with the following exceptions
One off low value items generally under £100 (or where appropriate use procurement card);
Subscriptions – procurement card or cheque application form; and
Specific products areas with the agreement of the Group Director of Procurement
Rent and rates, telecoms.

Authorisation for purchase is built within the E-financials and EDC system budgetary approval set in in line with Scheme of Delegation Register. The Trust does not accept liability for purchases undertaken outside the Trust Standing Financial Instructions.
Invoices for goods or services without a valid order number may be returned to suppliers
Competition/sourcing:

All procurement activity throughout the Trust will be conducted under the professional and ethical guidance provided by the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply. Public Procurement Regulations will also be adhered to, in conjunction with local Trust Standing Orders and Standing Financial Instructions.

Prior to undertaking any competition, a review of goods or services available through National and Regional Contracts/Framework Agreements should be performed. A Framework Agreement is a centrally pre-tendered list of suppliers available to the Trust and enabling the Trust to contract with, without the need to follow a more strenuous tendering procedure The Framework itself is not a contract but the ‘call off' from the Framework is a contract. Frameworks can be used for services, supplies and works and used in conjunction with the FTS procedures. Although it is sometimes possible to award directly to a supplier under the framework as well as run a ‘mini-competition' between suppliers capable of meeting the Trust's need, it is the procurement policy to run a mini-competition to ensure that the Trust is benefitting from best value for money for the required goods or services.

Evaluation of the range of items held on the NHS Supply Chain catalogue should also be undertaken in certain circumstances. Benchmarking price, quality and service of proposed purchases with other Trusts also proves valuable and is supported by the Procurement Department.

All staff authorised to approve the purchase of goods or services, and signing of invoices where appropriate, will be allocated to one of the following authorisation levels as per the Scheme of Delegation 5.1.
Authorisation levels for electronic ordering system:
Level 5 - Up to and including £7,499 per total order - must be approved by the Budget Holder/Authorised Signatory other Specified post holder.
Level 4 - £7,500 up to £25,000 per total order - must be approved by Budget Holder and Directorates or Divisional leads/Deputy site /Trust leads.
Level 3 - £25,000 up to £74,999 per total order - 9.1.4 must be approved by Budget holder and Directorates or Divisional leads/Deputy site /Trust leads.
Level 2 - £75,000 up Limit FTS Threshold per total order - must be approved by Group Director of Procurement, Chief Executive Office and Chief Finance officer.
The following levels have been revised and are in line with the MSE Trust's scheme of delegation April 2020:

Up to £250,000 per formal tender total - must be approved by the Procurement Business Partners/ Manager or Contract Manager and, Directorate or Divisional leads, and Group Director of Procurement/Deputy Group Director of Procurement or Chief Finance Officer.

£250,001 up to £500,000 per formal tender total - must be approved by the Procurement Business Partners/Manager or Contract Manager and, Directorates or Divisional leads and Group/ Deputy Group Director of Procurement and the Chief Executive Officer or Chief Financial Officer.

£500,001 up to £1m per formal tender total - must be approved by the Procurement Business Partners/Manager or Contract Manager and, Directorates or Divisional leads and Group/ Deputy Group Director of Procurement and the Chief Executive Officer and the Chief Financial Officer.

£1,000,001 and over per formal tender total - must be approved Procurement Business Partners/Manager or Contract Manager and, Directorates or Divisional leads and Group Director of Procurement, the Executive Team and the Trust board.
Tendering for goods and services

In order to ensure best VFM it is essential that competitive quotations or tenders are obtained. This is the case whether an item is to go onto the Trust catalogue or not. In determining the number of quotes or tenders to obtain consideration should be given to the likely volume of the goods or services to be required in the year ahead and subsequent years. The following are the quotation and tender requirements based on total life time costs (i.e. goods + x years maintenance) or total value over contract period.
The following financial limits are set out in the scheme of delegation (Refer to Appendix A):
Up to £7,499 – verbal quote required
From £7,500 - £24,499 – at least two written quotes using the Trust Quotation Form
From £25,000 - £74,499 – at least four written quotes using the Trust Quotation Form
From £75,000 –FTS Threshold– formal tender
Over FTS Threshold (see 5.8) will require publication in Find a Tender
Procurement objectives
To assist stakeholders in delivering best in care standards of service and meet their requirements whilst ensuring best VFM.
To protect the Trusts and minimise risk through means of appropriate managerial and contractual arrangements
To provide the tax payer with value for money through expenditure on procurement, demonstrating through annual savings plans benefiting patient care
To support the Trusts core objective of providing safe and excellent care to its patients and maintain its competitive advantage to the hospital of choice.

World Trade Organisation Procurement Directives, and the Public Contracts Regulations that implement them in the UK, set out the law on public procurement. Their purpose is to open up the public procurement market and to ensure the free movement of goods and services

The rules apply to purchases by public bodies and certain utilities which are above set monetary thresholds. They cover all WTO Members, because of international agreements, their benefits extend to a number of other countries worldwide. Where the Regulations apply, contracts must be advertised in the Find a Tender (“FTS”) and there are other detailed rules that must be followed. The purchase of all goods and services above the specified monetary thresholds are subject to the GPA regulations regardless of whether they are capital or revenue funded. Tendering
Once it is established that specific goods or services cannot be sourced through the above mentioned routes, the Trust should seek to obtain best value for money through competition.

This procedure is conducted in line with the Procurement Strategy and the Trust Standing Financial Instructions/Standing Orders. The Procurement Department must be contacted to lead tendering exercises for you and, in line with the DoH eProcurement Strategy (link below), utilise its online tendering portal. https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/nhs-e-procurement-strategy

Each tender must have a clear specification or scope and a scoring system agreed prior to the issue of documentation. The most economically advantageous tender (“MEAT”) will be awarded the business, provided that the total amount falls within the agreed budget. This scoring mechanism will be the basis for all debriefs to unsuccessful offerors. Guidance will be given by the Procurement Department in constructing the evaluation criteria, examples of which can be found in Section 2 of the Procurement Manual. Details of operational procedures relating to procurement can also be found in the Procurement Manual. All purchases/contracts which exceed the relevant European financial thresholds (except those where appropriate National Contracts are in place), will be advertised in the Find a tender (FTS), through the Procurement Department.
Failure to comply with Trust rules could result in disciplinary action. Failure to comply with the GPA could result in:
The High Court setting aside a contract (unable to proceed with contract award which will impact on services).
High Court claims for damages from companies denied the ability to participate in competitive tenders.
Infringement proceedings in the High Court
Supplier could claim for damages from the Trust for loss of economic opportunity
Damage in relationship with supplier impacting on delivery of the service.

Public sector contracts:

10.5.1 When entering into contracts the Trust will refuse to include contractual terms which purport to restrict the disclosure of information held by the Trust and relating to the contract beyond the restrictions permitted by the Act. Unless an exemption provided for under the Act is applicable in relation to any particular information, the Trust will be obliged to disclose that information in response to a request, regardless of the terms of any contract.

10.5.2 When entering into contracts with public or non-public authority contractors, the Trust may be under pressure to accept confidentiality clauses so that information relating to the terms of the contract, its value and performance will be exempt from disclosure. The Trust will reject such clauses wherever possible. Where, under exceptional circumstances, it is necessary to include non-disclosure provisions in a contract, the Trust will agree with the contractor a schedule of the contract which clearly identifies information which should not be disclosed and include provision that The Trust will be responsible for determining in its absolute discretion whether any of the content of the contract is exempt from disclosure in accordance with the provisions of the FOIA.
10.5.3 Any acceptance of such confidentiality provisions must be for good reasons and capable of being justified in the public interest and to The Information Commissioner.

10.5.4 It is for the Trust to disclose information pursuant to the Act, and not the contractor. The Trust will take steps to protect from disclosure by the contractor, information which the authority has provided to the contractor which would clearly be exempt from disclosure under the Act, by appropriate similar contractual terms. In order to avoid unnecessary secrecy, any such constraints will be drawn as narrowly as possible and according to the individual circumstances of the case. Apart from such cases, the Trust will not impose terms of secrecy on contractors.
Accepting Information in Confidence from Third Parties:

The Trust will only accept information from third parties in confidence if it is necessary to obtain that information in connection with the exercise of any of the authority's functions and it would not otherwise be provided.

The Trust will not agree to hold information received from third parties ‘in confidence' which is not confidential in nature. Again, acceptance of any confidentiality provisions must be for good reasons, be in the public interest and be capable of being justified to the Information Commissioner.
Information will be made available upon request within the remit of the prevailing NHS Terms and Conditions of Contract and the guidelines of the Freedom of Information Act.
Capital:

Capital Investment Group (“CIG”) - Under the chairmanship of the Director of Finance, this group considers and prioritises capital bids for equipment, which have been supported by the relevant sub group, and advise the Joint Board of Directors and Trust Board in accordance with Financial thresholds The Trust Board approves the annual Capital Programme and monitors it in year.
Medical Equipment:

Through a range of sub groups organised by the Medical Devices team, bids for medical equipment are considered and prioritised. They will receive professional support from procurement in defining the procurement plan, best value and development of a policy for equipment standardisation and product rationalisation.
Information Technology Systems:

Under the chairmanship of the Director of Informatics, this group will consider and prioritise bids for the purchase, lease and or installation of all IT equipment, software and IT systems, and will advise the Chief Executive accordingly. In addition all purchases, or introductions to the Trust by any means, of IT equipment, software and IT systems, outside of the capital bid process must also obtain prior approval from the Director of Informatics. Priority will be given to projects which have obtained appropriate approval and where approval has not been obtained, the deployment or installation of the IT item/s in question may be denied.
Buildings and Works:

Under the chairmanship of the Director of Environment / Head of Services for Estates and Facilities, this group considers and prioritises bids for developments and improvements to the fabric of the Trust. Expertise should be sought from the appropriate Procurement Lead.
Product user/Evaluation Groups:

These groups are set up on an ad hoc basis to evaluate products and ensure standardisation, best value and best practice with relevant specialty contribution for instance Infection Control, Health and Safety Officer and so forth. Please see our Code of Practice for Company Representatives for further details.
E-Commerce:

The Trust is committed to exploring electronic methods of communication, procurement and e-commerce both within the Trust and with Suppliers. All requisitions and orders should be placed using the Trust electronic ordering system, in order to minimise administrative costs, and to improve management reporting. We have a well-developed inventory and stock management system which is used for the requesting and ordering stock, and for managing the stock we have in- house. Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to the NHS' e- Procurement Strategy.
Contract Monitoring:
Key contracts will be regularly monitored to ensure that the Trust gains full value from the supplier, ensuring that suppliers adhere to agreed policies and performance indicators.
Ethics:
All staff involved with procurement must undertake to comply with the ethical code of purchasing provided by the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply.
Fair trade:
The Trust will endeavour to satisfy itself that all purchases are made from organisations advocating fair trade. It will not support purchases from organisations which exploits labour.
Environmental:
Consideration of the impact of all purchases on the environment will be made in all tenders.
Equality analysis:
Within each tender the equality impact will be assessed and will form part of the overall scoring as appropriate.
Local trading:

Where appropriate and in accordance with Public Procurement guidelines, the Trust will seek to support the regional economy using local suppliers. Debriefing of unsuccessful offerors will be led by a representative of the Procurement department, supported by user departments as appropriate.
Benchmarking:

The Trust will share information and best practice with other parts of the Health Service and Public Sector to measure the cost and effectiveness of its procurement processes. Benchmarking is an important part of the procurement process and the transparency and sharing of pricing information is supported in the NHS Terms and Conditions of Supply. Collaboration

The Trust will work with other NHS or Public Sector partners where appropriate to investigate the use of joint or consortium contracts when cost or service benefits can be identified. Collaborative organisations include:
East of England NHS Collaborative Procurement Hub http://www.eoecph.nhs.uk/
Retention of documents - Documents will be retained electronically via the Trust's IT infrastructure in the Procurement MSEB _ Shared Drive in conjunction with the retention schedule
Disposal of assets –The Director of Finance is responsible for preparing procedures for the disposal of assets. Please refer to the Corporate Governance Manual Section 16.13
Recommendation - This policy will be communicated through the Senior Managers Group (“SMG”) and will be available on the Trust Intranet.
Communication Plan - This policy will be communicated through the Senior Managers Group (“SMG”) and will be available on the Trust Intranet.
Training requirements
Procurement department staff will have appropriate training and updates based on professional qualification requirements.
All staff will be encouraged to attend training courses to develop their skills and knowledge on all aspects of Procurement.
